3.55.text: One of the ways that we thought that we could really prove

7.84.text: the business case for this is to get into Target.

9.94.text: And that would help us gain investment and really scale the business.

15.38.text: Because of the design sensibility and the sustainability of our

18.60.text: brand we thought: 'Hey this is going to be perfect for Target!'

21.02.text: We're going to go in there,

22.01.text: they are going to love this brand and it's going to be all good.

26.07.text: That wasn't an exactly how it went,

28.55.text: when we first went to Minneapolis.

30.95.text: This is an exact quote from the buyer

35.00.text: at the time who didn't like the name,

36.61.text: he didn't like us - he didn't like anything about it.

41.73.text: And so here you are as an entrepreneur.

43.95.text: You've invested your life savings in this thing,

46.73.text: You are going to your big whale that you are going to land

50.67.text: in order to take your business to the next level and you've

53.58.text: just been told 'a snowball's chance in hell.'

55.73.text: And so this was a low moment.

58.54.text: And it was one where - we have some values

62.26.text: at Method that I will talk about later,

64.30.text: but one of them is: what would Macgyver do?

69.39.text: which is a requirement of any startup.

72.82.text: And so, our first MacGyver moment was hiring and bringing

79.39.text: to the fold a famous designer named Karim Rashid.

84.33.text: This was a time when Target was,

86.01.text: starting with Michael Graves and other designers,

88.62.text: they were starting their cadence of bringing designers

91.87.text: into sort of what they called 'class for the masses'.

96.11.text: if we can - we are about design - and if we can really hook

99.26.text: ourselves up with a really well-known designer,

102.21.text: bring that design to the Method product,

104.13.text: then maybe we can get back in'.

112.32.text: So what we did is we used some of Eric's advertising connections and

117.50.text: we managed to get a meeting with the marketing group at Target.

120.57.text: So, keep in mind at most retailers the merchandisers or

123.62.text: the merchants are very different from the marketers.

125.58.text: So, the guys that run the - guys and gals that run the television

128.43.text: commercials are very different from the buyers.

130.72.text: And we've been told no by the buyers. So we go into the marketers.

135.80.text: And the marketers were more enthusiastic about this concept.

139.25.text: They saw the potential, the sizzle, they liked it,

141.91.text: you know, 'Okay this is a cool concept.'

144.27.text: And they invited some of the buyers in.

146.32.text: And we got Karim Rashid to fly to Minneapolis.

149.32.text: You know, he is a typical designer guy.

151.57.text: He's about 6'4" he was wearing a white suit and pink

154.56.text: goggles and has a larger than life presence.

159.38.text: And we put on this dog and pony show.

161.81.text: And of course the merchants were none too pleased

166.16.text: that we had kind of done this end around.

168.30.text: But what ended up happening during that meeting

171.51.text: is we - I was actually not at the meeting,

175.21.text: because I was developing this product up here on the right,

178.49.text: which is a dish soap that dispenses out of the bottom.

181.76.text: You pick it up and squeeze it and it dispenses out of

184.27.text: the bottom - based off of an insight that that would be

186.70.text: a better way of doing - of how to do hand dish washing.

191.05.text: So, I had developed this prototype,

193.69.text: of course, at the very last minute.

195.81.text: We sent it first overnight to Target,

198.12.text: the guys don't have any chance to squeeze

200.58.text: it or test it out or anything.

201.97.text: It goes around the table and the buyer who says

204.23.text: 'snowball's chance in hell' picks it up,

205.84.text: squeezes it and he said: 'Oh my gosh! Even I would buy this'.

209.57.text: And that was - the Hail Mary pass was complete

213.88.text: and we got our equivalent of our next chance,

218.09.text: which was: we got distribution in a hundred

221.51.text: Target stores on a test basis; 50 in Chicago, 50 in the Bay Area.

226.52.text: And - I will tell another quick story - in

231.73.text: we put our innovative Karim Rashid product up on the very top shelf.

235.90.text: Not realizing that what would happen

237.47.text: is people would look at this thing, very puzzled as to what it was.

240.95.text: Wanting to smell the fragrance they would rip the bottom off of it,

243.95.text: smell the fragrance, put it back on, and dish soap would start

247.67.text: to drip down the entire display.

250.51.text: You laugh, you laugh, but, that was another low moment where - I mean,

256.13.text: imagine you've got 100 stores, you finally got your shot,

258.76.text: you go into every store and there is dish soap all over everything.

262.18.text: And cleaning up dish soap is not fun.

265.04.text: And so, I hired all of my unemployed friends - which were many -

269.24.text: and we literally got into every one of those hundred stores

274.28.text: every two days for three months with wipes and paper towel,

280.17.text: And we had been given visibility to the data of how we were doing.

284.61.text: And the hurdle rates that we were given were the hurdle

287.72.text: rates of a national brand that's well known,

290.39.text: has 100% awareness on price discount on Encap.

296.13.text: we were unknown and we were not discounted at all - in fact,

298.70.text: we were premium priced. So, we weren't hitting those hurdles.

302.22.text: So, we go back in for our meeting to say: 'All right this is where

305.81.text: we are going to learn whether or not we are going national or not.

307.89.text: We didn't have very high expectations,

310.31.text: but fortunately one buyer started to look at the data and

313.65.text: realized that actually they weren't selling any less Dawn,

317.51.text: they weren't selling any less 409, or Windex.

320.78.text: Because when they were selling Method we

322.74.text: are actually incremental to the category,

324.33.text: we are much more profitable for them than a lot of the

327.28.text: other commodity brands that they carry in the space.

333.69.text: we were actually given national distribution.
